channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [SEC-3005] prePostEnabled set to true on @EnableGlobalMethodSecurity ignores AspectJ mode
item.description:
Using Java Config, AspectJ mode is ignored when "prePostEnabled" is set to true on @EnableGlobalMethodSecurity. If only "secured" is set to true, AspectJ mode is honoured. This has been reported previously - see SEC-2595 and SEC-2698. This causes proxy classes to be created and internal method calls annotated with @PreAuthorize are bypassed.

The sample project - aspectj-jc - only sets secured to true so the AspectjInterceptorTests.notProxy() test passes.

The issue is not present with xml config.

My workaround is to remove the @EnableGlobalMethodSecurity annotation and create an xml config with this entry:

<security:global-method-security
 
		secured-annotations="enabled" mode="aspectj" pre-post-annotations="enabled">
 
		<security:expression-handler ref="expressionHandler" />
 
</security:global-method-security>

and include it in my Java config:

@ImportResource(value = "classpath:/applicationContext-sec.xml")
item.summary: prePostEnabled set to true on @EnableGlobalMethodSecurity ignores AspectJ mode

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Thanks for the report. Can you provide more details?

You may notice that the only aspect provided by Spring Security is AnnotationSecurityAspect which only works with the Secured annotations. This means that out of the box Spring Security does not provide an aspect for AspectJ and prePostEnabled (so you should not expect that this will work). This means that the following will not work out of the box:

@EnableGlobalMethodSecurity(mode = AdviceMode.ASPECTJ, prePostEnabled = true)

Similarly, the following will not work either:

<security:global-method-security
 
		mode="aspectj" pre-post-annotations="enabled">
 
		
</security:global-method-security>

It should be noted that in AspectJ mode the secured-enabled and pre-post-enabled attributes only impact the voters that are registered. It is the classpath and the joinpoints on the aspects that determine what is woven at compile time.

I noticed your XML configuration has secured-annotations="enabled" also. Perhaps that is why it is working (i.e. you have Secured annotations on your service too)?

Thanks Rob.

I had looked at the source for AnnotationSecurityAspect before logging this issue and, as far as I can tell, it does support PreAuthorize and PostAuthorize annotations. From the source in Spring Security 4.0.1:

/**
 
     * Matches the execution of any method with the Secured annotation.
 
     */
 
    private pointcut executionOfSecuredMethod() :
 
        execution(* *(..)) && @annotation(Secured);
 
 
 
    /**
 
     * Matches the execution of any method with Pre/Post annotations.
 
     */
 
    private pointcut executionOfPrePostAnnotatedMethod() :
 
        execution(* *(..)) && (@annotation(PreAuthorize) || @annotation(PreFilter)
 
                || @annotation(PostAuthorize) || @annotation(PostFilter));
 
 
 
    private pointcut securedMethodExecution() :
 
        executionOfAnyPublicMethodInAtSecuredType() ||
 
        executionOfSecuredMethod() ||
 
        executionOfPrePostAnnotatedMethod();
 
 
 
    Object around(): securedMethodExecution() {
 
        if (this.securityInterceptor == null) {
 
            return proceed();
 
        }
 
 
 
        AspectJCallback callback = new AspectJCallback() {
 
            public Object proceedWithObject() {
 
                return proceed();
 
            }
 
        };
 
 
 
        return this.securityInterceptor.invoke(thisJoinPoint, callback);
 
    }

Am I missing something?

Craig Chapman Thanks for the fast reply and detailed response. I left out an important detail.

The current implementation of AnnotationSecurityAspect does not support prePostEnabled for annotations appearing at the class level. For example, the following will have no impact with AspectJ mode:

@PreAuthorize("hasRole('USER')")
 
public class SecuredService {
 
   ...
 
}

It does work for annotated methods. For example, the following will work:

@PreAuthorize("hasRole('USER')")
 
public void secureMethod() {
 
 
 
}

Is this perhaps the issue you are encountering? Regardless if this is your issue, it is something we should fix (just need to determine if this will be a new JIRA or this one).

I pushed a branch to my fork (rwinch/spring-security/SEC-3005) that demonstrates that prePostEnabled does work (at method level but not class level) and does not create a proxy.

If this does not help, perhaps it would be easiest for you to provide a complete test case for me to run?

Thanks Rob.

I'm almost certain I wasn't using the Pre/Post annotations at class level. Let me revisit this in the next few days and will let you know when I can reproduce - with supporting config/code.
Thanks. I'll note that I plan on doing a release next week, so if you can get back to me quickly I will be more likely to include a fix in the releases next week. Thanks again.

Hi Rob,

See attached spring starter project that demonstrates the issue I have encountered. You'll see that if you change "prePostEnabled = true" to "securedEnabled = true" the test passes.

Let me know if I can be of any more help.

Cheers,
Craig

Craig,

Thanks for the fast turnaround.

I have not been able to reproduce the root problem you were encountering. So please ensure to continue reading (I just want to make sure we sort everything out).

I have been able to isolate why the class is proxied in your example, but not mine. The sample you provided is registering InfrastructureAdvisorAutoProxyCreator via Spring Boot's auto configuration. This in turn is matching on Spring Security's MethodSecurityMetadataSourceAdvisor.

This is certainly an issue, but I have not been able to reproduce the root problem you were encountering. Specifically, you stated

This causes proxy classes to be created and internal method calls annotated with @PreAuthorize are bypassed.

However, at this point in my testing I have been unable to reproduce this. I've refactored your sample slightly. You can run JavaTests#callsSecured() and see that the test is passing (i.e. the internal method call is secured). Note that all the tests are in the BaseTest to ensure consistent tests across environments.

Another thing to ensure is that the application you are using annotates the implementation with @PreAuthorize rather than the interface since AspectJ does not respect annotations on the interface.

Also to elaborate on the statement:

You'll see that if you change "prePostEnabled = true" to "securedEnabled = true" the test passes.

This is true. However, that is due to the fact that you do not have a @Secured annotation on the UserServiceImpl. If you add the annotation, then the class will be proxied.

Thanks again for the report and for your continued efforts in isolating these bugs!

I have pushed out a fix to master that resolves incorrectly proxying Spring Security related Advice when using ASPECTJ mode. This specific issue is now tracked as SEC-3045 You can try that by using 4.0.2.BUILD-SNAPSHOT as outlined in Getting Spring Security.

Hi Rob,

I have spent a bit of time trying to reproduce the bypassing of internal method calls in ASPECTJ mode and haven't been able to. Perhaps ASPECTJ mode was not enabled when I ran the final test before reporting the issue or some other configuration I had was affecting the test. I was playing about with the config quite a bit to resolve the proxy issue and perhaps there was a side effect in doing so. I guess I also wasn't expecting internal calls to security annotated methods to work since the class was proxied. It is well documented that internal calls to security annotated methods has no effect in AdviceMode.PROXY.

In any event, I have tried out 4.0.2.CI-SNAPSHOT and the issue of proxying when in ASPECTJ mode is resolved.

Thanks for the quick fix and apologies if you wasted time on the security bypassing issue I reported.

Cheers,
Craig

Also worth mentioning something else I came across the other day...

I was attempting to add JSR-303 validation to my service layer and annotated the class with org.springframework.validation.annotation.Validated. This caused the service class to be proxied and the proxy test to fail. Not sure what the side effects would have been but it highlights the value in having the proxy test when in ASPECTJ mode.

In any event, I have tried out 4.0.2.CI-SNAPSHOT and the issue of proxying when in ASPECTJ mode is resolved.

Glad to hear it! I will mark this issue as superseded by SEC-3045 then.

Thanks for the quick fix and apologies if you wasted time on the security bypassing issue I reported.

No apologies necessary! Thank you very much for reporting the issue and your quick responses!

I was attempting to add JSR-303 validation to my service layer and annotated the class with org.springframework.validation.annotation.Validated. This caused the service class to be proxied and the proxy test to fail. Not sure what the side effects would have been but it highlights the value in having the proxy test when in ASPECTJ mode.

Can you create a separate issue for this with details on how to reproduce (perhaps a sample)?

Hi Rob,

I have created SEC-3049 for the JSR-303 issue.

Cheers,
Craig
This issue has been migrated to https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-security/issues/3216
